subtopic: Livestock and Animal Husbandry,Crops and Crop Management Systems,Economic Theory & Research,Agricultural Research,Environmental Economics & Policies

0.cdata!: Uruguay - Quinto Proyecto De Desarrollo Ganadero

abstracts.cdata!:
The Fifth Livestock Development Project
            was designed to continue assistance to Uruguay's
            national livestock development program by providing medium-
            and long-term credit to beef cattle and sheep ranchers,
            dairy farmers, pork producers and machinery contractors. The
            project's objectives were to expand beef and milk
            production so as to enable Uruguay to increase meat exports,
            to substitute domestically produced dairy products for
            imports, and help the Government to improve sector policies.
            The strategy used for meeting project objectives was to: (a)
            step up pasture production through use of phosphates
            fertilizer and better seeds; (b) improve ranch and farm
            management by constructing fences, water points, and cattle
            handling facilities; and (c) initiate product
            diversification on small-scale farm holdings. The
            quantitative assessment of the impact of credit projects is
            traditionally difficult, but the more so in this case for
            two reasons: (a) although there is a project monitoring unit
            with an excellent data base of relevant records on a sample
            basis, it is too early to evaluate the effects of on-ranch
            project investment on technical coefficients and production;
            and (b) the country's sector policies have been
            unstable and changes occurred in the international beef
            markets upon which Uruguay depends, and which had an impact
            on the sector difficult to quantify.
